We have implemented a simple version of this. It's attached to this mail (I'm unsure if attachments get removed)

We use that exactly to limit load on domain-level and to limit the overall number of fetches / bytes on domain-level (with the QuotaEnforcer 
module which has the notion of Groups following the QueueAssignmentPolicy)

best
-- 
Bjarne Andersen

pandae667 wrote:
> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
> 
>>pandae667 wrote:
>>
>>>Dear IA-Team,
>>>
>>>I'm wondering if there is something like a
>>>DomainQueueAssignementPolicy (I need this to make sure not to crawl
>>>more than one host located on the same domain at once - otherwise I
>>>might DoS customers that use loads of different sub-hostnames for
>>>different purposes.)
>>>
>>>If nothing alike exists yet I'd implement such a policy based upon
>>>SurtAuthorityQueueAssignmentPolicy.
>>
>>Nothing like that yet exists.
>>
>>If it is only an issue only for a certain known set of domains, you can 
>>use the "force-queue-assignment" frontier setting in a domain override 
>>to force all URIs in subdomains into the same queue.
>>
>>(Specifically: if this setting is non-empty, all URIs to which the 
>>setting applies will have this string, rather than the string given by 
>>the assignment-policy, as its queue name.)
>>
>>A policy to do this would be a valuable contribution. Of course, for 
>>different top-level-domains the number of domain-segments that reflect 
>>"same domain" (in a meaningful shared-ownership sense) varies.
>>
>>- Gordon @ IA
>>
> 
> Hi Gordon,
> 
> I do agree that it would be usefull to make such an AssignementPolicy
> configurable - but it seems to me like this isn't an available option.
> To offer something like addElementToDefinition the class would need to
> extend ComplexType - but currently those AssignementPolicies are based
> upon the abstract class QueueAssignementPolicy.
> Additionally to this shortcoming I don't know how the webUI
> would/should handle this case. The assignement policies are listed in
> a dropdown box on the settings page - thus propably offering no way to
> set additional options.
> 
> Regards
>   Olaf Freyer
> 
> 



--Boundary_(ID_dx0TJIqk0iapedXL69nPPw)
